data.text: @MaxKashevsky Ta, little bit at a time, I guess. Caught it at ComicCon. Hoping no one gave it to Jodie or Mandip.
@MaxKashevsky Currently in the same boat. My Mum also works in the NHS and she says you can usually get a definitive result after 10 minutes
@MaxKashevsky @milneorchid More accurately what I should have said is it's a test for a marker correlated to infectiousness, not infection.

@MaxKashevsky @milneorchid But technically speaking this is still an 'infectiousness' test, even though the viral load they respond to is practially speaking not enough to be a risk. They don't detect COVID if you don't have viral load (for example if it's in your spinal fluid).

@MaxKashevsky @milneorchid [...] the tests responding to truly tiny amounts of viral load *after* the infection. So they lag both ways. They don't detect infection until viral load accumulates, and they continue detecting viral load once it has accumulated even when it falls to very low levels.

@MaxKashevsky @milneorchid Well, they test viral load - particles in the back of the nose and throat - and viral load correlates to infectiousness. So if you get infected you don't start testing positive until that load has accumulated, whereas what is happening here is [...]
@Eiphel @milneorchid I thought it was the latter? This is from a Guardian article from December: https://t.co/tPrxweG1Uo
@milneorchid @MaxKashevsky Thing to note is that an LFT is testing whether you infect*ious* not infect*ed*.
